title: Students who hugged after raping woman in nightclub face jail
text:
To view this video please enable JavaScript, and consider upgrading to a web browser that supports HTML5 video

Two Italian postgraduate students who hugged and high-fived after filming each other raping a woman in a nightclub are facing jail.

Ferdinando Orlando, 25, and Lorenzo Costanzo, 26, attacked the 23-year-old at the Toy Room Club in Soho just six minutes after meeting her on the dancefloor.

Advertisement

Advertisement

The woman was passed between the two men each taking turns in kissing her and then dragged to a dingy maintenance room and raped twice by each, leaving her needing surgery.

Prosecutor Allison Hunter QC said the pair carried the incapacitated woman to the toilet and ran straight upstairs and outside ‘where they can be seen hugging, high-fiving each other, strong arming, laughing and looking at what appear to be images or video on a mobile phone’.

Both men claimed the woman consented, but jurors at Isleworth Crown Court found them both guilty of two counts of rape.

They will be sentenced on a date to be fixed.

Ferdinando Orlando and Lorenzo Costanzo face years behind bars (Picture: Universal News And Sport (Europe))

The court heard the woman had been drinking since 11am on 25 February 2017 to celebrate a friend’s birthday.

She told police she was a ‘10’ on a scale of drunkenness at the time of the attack.

Ms Hunter told jurors the club’s CCTV showed the trio meeting on the dancefloor where the two pals ‘can be seen to pass her from one to the other, each of them taking it in turns to kiss her’.

Orlando then steered her towards the maintenance room with Constanzo in tow and the woman recalled from the witness box that ‘it was hard to get away from them’ because they were ‘the support for me walking’.

CCTV showed the pair breaking off the locks to the maintenance room before throwing her inside and attacking her in the darkened room.

Advertisement

Advertisement

All three emerged again 16 minutes later, with the two men seen to re-arrange the woman’s dress before propelling her towards the bathroom and fleeing.

Their victim was not found by staff until an hour later and was eventually escorted outside where she described being in extreme pain and was barely able to hold herself upright.

A French couple help the victim home but her housemate realised she was in such severe pain that London Ambulance Service and police were called.

It was only a year later when Costanzo returned to the UK to watch a football match in London that he was arrested at Heathrow Airport and taken into custody.

Following Costanzo’s arrest, Orlando contacted the police and flew back by appointment where he was arrested.

Orlando is studying a postgraduate degree in International Law while Costanzo is taking a postgraduate masters degree in Business and Management.

The maintenance room where the woman was attacked (Picture: Universal News And Sport (Europe))

Detective Sergeant Rebecca Woodsford, who led the investigation, said: ‘Today’s result is the best possible outcome from a truly traumatic experience for the victim, who suffered severe injuries which resulted in her suspecting she may have been raped.

‘Her discovery prompted the police investigation where the attack by these two men was identified.

Advertisement

‘Costanzo and Orlando thought that they could attack a vulnerable victim, brag about it and then get away with it. They were very wrong and will now pay the price for their actions.’

Christina Smith of the CPS said: ‘These two rapists have at every turn denied responsibility for their sickening actions.

‘They took advantage of a vulnerable woman, who had clearly lost the capacity to consent to sexual activity.

‘They ushered her into a room, raped her, discarded her and then ran away from the scene of their crime in callous celebration.

‘The victim has shown immense courage in coming forward and we hope these convictions provide her with some comfort.

‘We hope this serves as a very strong reminder that anyone who takes advantage of another who, for whatever reason, is unable to consent faces prosecution for their actions.’
